caption: An historical place in Paris with links to both Louis XIV and the Revolution. If you are in the area worth a visit, some good local restaurants. Also an interesting cemetery close by.
This place is huge and beautiful most of all when the sun sets the dark rises and the lights are turning up. It's a place to go.
Looks good. Worth stoping by if you're close to Nation. Has an amazing restaurant to the left of the left column.

The Throne columns are all that remains of the Throne barrier, built in 1787 as a grant barrier for the Farmers General enclosure.  It had two gatehouses framing a 60-meter grid and served as a pedestal for two monumental columns 28 meters high. In 1845, the lower parts of the columns were decorated with bas-reliefs and the columns were topped with statues of Saint-Louis and Philippe Auguste.

Built in 1787, the barrier is classified as a historic monument, the columns were topped by two statues 3.8 meters high: Philippe Auguste and Saint Louis. They are simply magnificent and very, very large.

The Barrier du Tr√¥ne is an ancient grant where tax was paid on goods coming to Paris. It is also approximately towards the southern column that the last location of the guillotine was located during the Terror.  The two beautiful columns which frame the start of the Cours de Vincennes are beautiful and bright. We appreciate the statues of Saint Louis and Philippe Auguste, as well as their slender silhouette! From there you can visit the Cours and its market, and for history lovers, the Picpus cemetery with the tomb of Lafayette and the Carmelites of Compi√®gne among others.  I highly recommend

It's always interesting to discover the history and secrets of Parisian monuments. The Barri√®re du Tr√¥ne is an emblematic place that deserves to be visited. Located at the corner of Avenue du Tr√¥ne and Boulevard de Picpus, it is decorated with two statues: that of Philippe Auguste sculpted by Dumont is located on the 12th arrondissement side and that of Saint Louis sculpted by Etex is located on the 11th arrondissement side.  The latter is also at the origin of the statue of G√©ricault du P√®re Lachaise, which makes him a very talented artist.  A visit to the Barri√®re du Tr√¥ne is therefore an excellent opportunity to admire his work from afar, of course, but while waiting to have the right to use a drone in town, which may take time (or which will not happen in order to to avoid certain excesses) it will be necessary to be content with this observation distance.  Another possibility would be to use a 150-600 mm instead of the 85 mm used for these images but you would still have to find the right spot from which to shoot.. To be continued...

Built in 1787 to the plans of the architect¬†Claude Nicolas Ledoux, it included two gatehouses framing a grid of approximately 60 meters and serving as a¬†pedestal for two columns 28 meters high. To the east, two identical pavilions housed the offices and housing of the tax clerks.

It takes its name from the old Place du Tr√¥ne, it starts from Place de la Nation and continues on Avenue de Vincennes. Like many works and monuments in the city of Paris, it is in perfect condition. Some things to see if you are in the neighborhood.

The columns of the Throne stand proudly towards the sky at a height of 28 m. turned, both looking towards Vincennes. The two figures at the top were placed in the following century. On the right column on the 11th side, it is Louis IX known as Saint Louis with an extender in his left hand, representing Justice and Peace. On the left column, 12th side, it is Philippe Auguste, sword in his right hand raised towards the sky which represents Victory and Abundance. Both having a ‚Äúdifferent‚Äù attachment to Vincennes justifies their presence here. The base of the columns features an allegory representing Victory.

this place is full of history, each column has its pavilion one of them supports the statue of Philippe Auguste and the other that of St Louis, during the revolution the guillotine was operating at full capacity at Place de la Nation. ps: the throne barrier is a component of the old fortifications which encompassed the entire capital in the 19th and 20th century. consult the archives of the time it's really very interesting.
Monument steeped in history, linked to the French Revolution. Located at Place de la Nation
It is a very original and friendly monument located next to the Place de la Nation. To visit

The royal statues of ‚ÄúSaint‚Äù-Louis IX and Philippe II ‚ÄúAuguste‚Äù demarcate the ‚Äúbarrier‚Äù of attribution (toll), authorizing access to the city. Topologically symmetrical to the place of the star, to which it is connected by the "enclosure" (wall) of the general "farmers" delimiting the interior districts bordering it ("fields", mention which is found in numerous toponymies between this wall and the previous ones) and the external villages (Charonne, Picpus). The razed wall allowed the construction of wide concentric avenues which took the name of the neighboring villages.
It attracted me from afar

Nothing extraordinary, two immense columns surmounted by two figures that can barely be made out, it was formerly the eastern gate of Paris with its two grant pavilions (which still exist) where one had to pay taxes. 'a right to be able to enter the capital

Now that you have read the comments of two or three uneducated people, let's start again: the columns of the throne are not from the 19th century but from the 18th (1787... just before the revolution). An order placed by customs with Claude-Nicolas Ledoux (at the same time as eight other buildings of the same type surrounding Paris)... Today only two remain: the buildings of the Place du Throne and the posterns of Place Denfert Rochereau. a gate closed Paris at night to prevent vehicles from entering. During the day, customs collected entry taxes into the city and also acted as a health barrier to goods that could represent a risk. the Statutes representing Philippe-Auguste and Saint-Louis were added in the middle of the 19th century... Just in case customs didn't impress you!
beautiful place, steeped in the history of France. Don't forget the small Picpus cemetery 300m away where Lafayette is buried. And many other famous ones

Few people notice the historic nature of these columns and ignore them when passing by. It's a shame because it's part of the culture of Paris.
